question: Will the state of Delaware's Division of Corporations list OpenAI as an "Exempt" entity on March 31, 2025?
description: [Exclusive: OpenAI to remove non-profit control and give Sam Altman equity](https://www.reuters.com/technology/artificial-intelligence/openai-remove-non-profit-control-give-sam-altman-equity-sources-say-2024-09-25/)
fine_print: The specific link to the website of the resolution source is provided for convenience, but if the resolution data is at a different page at the resolution source, then that will be used for resolution.
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**OpenAI Not for Sale, Says CEO Sam Altman Amidst Elon Musk's $94.7 Billion Offer**
OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has stated that the company is not for sale, despite Elon Musk's offer of $94.7 billion. Altman said, 'Our structure ensures that no individual can take control of OpenAI. These are tactics to try to weaken us because we are making great progress.' The company's board may not be able to ignore the offer, as it involves two jurisdictions: California and Delaware. Altman has rejected Musk's offer, saying, 'The OpenAI mission is not for sale.' He also stated that the company's current structure prevents any individual from taking control. Musk has been trying to acquire OpenAI for a long time, and Altman sees this as just another attempt. The company is planning to restructure its operations, separating its commercial division from its non-profit board. Altman said that the board has not yet determined a valuation for the company's operations, and the process is ongoing.
Original language: pt
Publish date: February 12, 2025 01:32 AM
Source:[Estadão](https://www.estadao.com.br/link/empresas/openai-nao-esta-a-venda-diz-sam-altman-apos-musk-oferecer-us-94-bi-pela-empresa-nprei/)

**Elon Musk's $97bn offer is a nuisance for Sam Altman's OpenAI**
Elon Musk has made a $97bn unsolicited bid for OpenAI, a non-profit entity that controls the world's leading developer of artificial-intelligence models. However, the bid is seen as a spoiler by OpenAI's boss, Sam Altman, who is in an escalating feud with Musk over the transition to a more orthodox, profit-seeking corporate structure. Musk claims this would be a betrayal of OpenAI's original safety-first mission, but insiders believe he is determined to hobble the biggest competitor to his rival company, x. OpenAI has swiftly rejected the bid and is raising $40bn from investors, including SoftBank. Musk's lawyers have urged the attorneys-general of California and Delaware to scrutinise the change in OpenAI's ownership structure, threatening a bidding war if they do not. As Jill Horwitz, professor of law at the University of California, Los Angeles, says, 'the board's fiduciary duty is to act in line with Open's legal purpose, which is to build superhuman intelligence that is 'safe and benefits all of humanity.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: February 11, 2025 09:48 PM
Source:[The Economist](https://www.economist.com/business/2025/02/11/elon-musks-97bn-offer-is-a-nuisance-for-sam-altmans-openai)

**Musk's Unsolicited Bid Sparks Turmoil Over OpenAI Control | Politics**
Elon Musk's consortium has made an unsolicited bid to acquire control of OpenAI, aiming to prevent its transition from a nonprofit to a for-profit entity. However, OpenAI's board claims it hasn't received a formal bid and intends to reject the offer. According to OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, Musk's bid is 'another tactic to disrupt the company's mission.' The bid has sparked legal complexities, with Delaware Attorney General Kathy Jennings reviewing OpenAI's plans to ensure they align with public charitable purposes. Legal experts warn that Musk's bid may complicate the valuation of OpenAI's nonprofit assets during its corporate transition, necessitating regulatory scrutiny.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 11, 2025 09:22 PM
Source:[Devdiscourse](https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3261716-musks-unsolicited-bid-sparks-turmoil-over-openai-control)

**OpenAI's Altman says Musk offer is tactic 'to try to mess with us'**
OpenAI CEO Sam Altman has rejected Elon Musk's offer to buy the nonprofit that controls ChatGPT maker OpenAI, calling it a 'tactic to try to mess with us.' The offer, worth $97.4 billion, was made by a consortium led by Musk, but OpenAI's board has not received a formal bid. Altman said the company is not for sale and plans to reject the offer based on its mission. The move is part of OpenAI's transition to a for-profit entity, which it says is required to secure the capital needed for developing the best AI models. Delaware Attorney General Kathy Jennings is reviewing OpenAI's proposed changes to ensure the company is adhering to its charitable purposes. Legal experts say Musk's bid complicates the fair value of OpenAI's charitable assets in the conversion to a for-profit entity.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 11, 2025 04:47 PM
Source:[reuters.com](https://www.reuters.com/technology/artificial-intelligence/openais-altman-says-musk-offer-is-tactic-to-try-mess-with-us-2025-02-11/)

**Elon Musk heads group trying to buy control of OpenAI: report**
Elon Musk is leading an investment group offering $97.4 billion to buy control of OpenAI, the nonprofit that controls ChatGPT, according to a report by the Wall Street Journal. OpenAI's board of directors has received the bid, submitted by Musk's attorney Marc Toberoff. In response, OpenAI chief Sam Altman wrote on X, 'No thank you, but we will buy Twitter for $9.74 billion if you want.' Musk replied with a single word: 'Swindler.' The move marks a new front in Musk's ongoing feud with Altman, who has been at odds with Musk since he left OpenAI in 2018. OpenAI has outlined a plan to become a Delaware Public Benefit Corporation, which would balance the interests of shareholders, stakeholders, and the public. Musk has established his own generative AI startup, xAI, to compete with OpenAI.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 11, 2025 12:02 PM
Source:[rawstory.com](https://www.rawstory.com/elon-musk-heads-group-trying-to-buy-control-of-openai-report/)

**Musk Offers $97.4 Billion for OpenAI, Altman Responds with Twitter Offer**
Elon Musk has proposed a $97.4 billion acquisition of OpenAI, a non-profit organization that controls the chatbot developer ChatGPT. However, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman responded on X, saying, 'No thanks, but we can buy Twitter for $9.74 billion if you want.' Musk acquired Twitter in 2022 for $44 billion and renamed it X. Musk, a co-founder of OpenAI who left the board in 2018, has disagreed with the company's transition to commercial activity. He has taken OpenAI and Altman to court over the commercialization of the company, claiming it has been transformed into a de facto subsidiary of Microsoft with closed-source code. Musk stated, 'It's time for OpenAI to return to open-source code.' His AI startup X.AI, which was founded in March 2023, may merge with OpenAI after the deal. Musk has also gained the support of several investors, including Valor Equity Partners, Baron Capital, and others. In January, Musk's lawyer Mark Tobeyroff sent a letter to the California and Delaware attorneys general requesting an auction to sell his stake in OpenAI. OpenAI has called Musk's legal claims unfounded. In December, the company published documents showing that Musk supported the transformation of OpenAI into a commercial entity but left because he couldn't gain control over it.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 11, 2025 08:19 AM
Source:[Oxu.Az](https://oxu.az/ru/v-mire/mask-predlozhil-pochti-100-mlrd-dollarov-za-openai-altman-sdelal-vstrechnoe-predlozhenie)

**Musk's Bid to Acquire OpenAI Met with Resistance from CEO Sam Altman**
Elon Musk's investment group has made a bid to acquire OpenAI for $974 billion, with the possibility of merging with his AI company xAI. However, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman responded by saying, 'No thanks, but if you want, we can buy Twitter (now X) for $97.4 billion.' This was a reference to Musk's previous purchase of Twitter for $44 billion in 2022. Musk responded by calling Altman a 'scammer' and posting a video of Altman saying he didn't receive any stock from OpenAI. Altman also sent an open letter to OpenAI employees, saying, 'Our organizational structure ensures that no individual can control OpenAI... (Musk's bid) is an attempt to undermine our strategy, as we are making significant progress.' OpenAI had previously announced a restructuring plan in December 2024 to convert its profitable business into a public benefit corporation (PBC) in Delaware, while its non-profit department would continue to exist. Musk's group is trying to acquire the non-profit department, which Musk believes may be undervalued when OpenAI separates it from the PBC.

**Pennsylvania Act 122: Understanding Key Reporting Requirements and Deadlines for Businesses in 2025**
The Pennsylvania Department of State offers online guidelines and filing instructions for businesses to comply with Act 122's new reporting requirements. The reporting period opened on January 6, 2025, with filing deadlines and costs determined by the type of registered entity. There is a $7 filing fee for corporations, LLCs, and other entities, while nonprofits are exempt. Failure to comply will result in penalties, including administrative dissolution or cancellation of registration, but businesses will have a transition period until 2027. It's essential to note that Act 122's requirements differ from federal obligations under the Corporate Transparency Act, and businesses should consult with their legal advisors to ensure compliance with both state and federal regulations.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 10, 2025 07:54 PM
Source:[JD Supra](https://www.jdsupra.com/legalnews/pennsylvania-act-122-understanding-key-1429018/)

**OpenAI aims to become public benefit corp.**
OpenAI has outlined plans to transform from a non-profit to a for-profit entity, but with a twist. The company aims to become a Delaware Public Benefit Corporation, which would give its for-profit arm more freedom while still allowing it to pursue charitable initiatives. According to OpenAI, this new structure would result in 'one of the best resourced non-profits in history.' Under the current structure, the non-profit board controls the for-profit arm, but under the new structure, the board would focus on charitable initiatives while leaving commercial operations to the public benefit corporation.

**OpenAI to Transform into For-Profit Structure in 2025, Raises Concerns Among Tech Moguls**
OpenAI plans to transform into a for-profit structure in 2025, aiming to raise more funds to maintain its lead in the expensive AI competition and promote the development of its non-profit business. According to CNBC and Reuters, OpenAI will restructure its existing for-profit department into a Public Benefit Corporation (PBC) in Delaware, while its non-profit department will hold a significant amount of equity in the for-profit department, providing ample resources for charitable activities in healthcare, education, and scientific research. OpenAI stated that the transformation into a hybrid non-profit/for-profit structure will help secure more funding and emphasized the need to 'raise significantly more money than we thought' and 'transition to a traditional equity-based model.' After restructuring, the company will also be exempt from some restrictions imposed on new companies and non-profit organizations. OpenAI aims to become a sustainable company by 2025, achieving its mission of developing 'artificial general intelligence' (AGI) that benefits humanity. However, OpenAI's plan to transform into a for-profit entity has been opposed by tech moguls like Elon Musk, who believes that OpenAI will struggle to balance its profit and social benefits, and Musk has even called it a 'scam' on his X platform.

**OpenAI Set to Transition to Public Benefit Corporation to Fuel AGI Mission**
OpenAI is planning to transition into a Delaware Public Benefit Corporation (PBC) to enhance its mission of advancing artificial general intelligence (AGI) for the benefit of humanity. The dual entity system will comprise a non-profit and for-profit arm, allowing for more robust fundraising efforts while maintaining the core mission. This change is expected to make the non-profit one of the most well-resourced in history, enabling it to tackle significant challenges in healthcare, education, and science. OpenAI aims to scale up its technological impact and keep pace with global shifts in technology infrastructure, including changes in energy, land use, and data management. By redefining its operational model, OpenAI hopes to balance AI's potential benefits against the risks and ensure a positive impact on global communities, as stated by the organization.

OpenAI, the maker of ChatGPT, is considering restructuring its corporate structure to address ongoing criticism of its legal setup. The company is mulling converting its for-profit division into a Delaware Public Benefit Corporation (PBC), a legal structure that balances shareholder, stakeholder, and public benefit interests. **OpenAI Changes Business Model: From Non-Profit to For-Profit**
OpenAI, a leader in the development of artificial intelligence, has announced its decision to become a for-profit organization. In a recent blog post, the company explained that this change is necessary to maintain its primary mission of 'ensuring that General Artificial Intelligence (AGI) benefits all humanity.' This transition represents a significant shift from the company's non-profit origins in 2015. The decision was motivated primarily by the increasing costs of managing AI, with servers equipped with Nvidia Blackwell chips costing over $3 million. Despite controversy, this move appears inevitable to remain competitive in the sector. OpenAI will transform into a Public Benefit Corporation of Delaware. Currently, OpenAI operates as a 'limited' for-profit company with two divisions: the for-profit and non-profit. The non-profit division and its board of directors govern all of OpenAI's activities. The for-profit division can issue shares to raise capital, but remains under the control of the non-profit. To attract more investments, OpenAI is now switching to a completely for-profit model. Investors see the current profit limit (100 times the initial investment) as an obstacle. All residual value created beyond this threshold is returned to the non-profit division. Financial projections indicate that OpenAI may suffer a loss of $5 billion this year, against revenues of $3.7 billion. These numbers have likely influenced the decision to become a for-profit company to secure the necessary funding to maintain a competitive advantage. OpenAI plans to transform its current for-profit subsidiary into a Public Benefit Corporation (PBC) of Delaware, a business entity created for public and social benefit. The company has stated that ordinary shares and OpenAI's mission will be the public benefit interests of this entity. The non-profit division will maintain its philanthropic goals in areas such as healthcare, education, and science. It will have a 'significant interest' in the PBC in the form of equally valued shares by independent consultants. OpenAI claims that this structure will make its non-profit division one of the best-funded in history.
Original language: it
Publish date: December 28, 2024 01:47 PM
Source:[tomshw.it](https://www.tomshw.it/hardware/openai-cambia-business-moel-da-no-profit-a-for-profit-2024-12-28)

**OpenAI Plans to Restructure Company into For-Profit and Non-Profit Entities**
OpenAI has announced plans to restructure its company, separating into a for-profit and a non-profit entity. The board of directors stated that they are evaluating the company's structure to best achieve their mission of ensuring that general-purpose artificial intelligence benefits all humanity. According to a statement, OpenAI plans to convert its existing for-profit business into a Public Benefit Corporation (PBC) in Delaware, which requires the company to balance the interests of shareholders, stakeholders, and the public. The non-profit department of OpenAI will continue to exist and become one of the 'most resource-rich non-profit organizations in history', and will hold shares in the restructured PBC. If the restructuring is completed, the PBC will be responsible for OpenAI's operations and business, while the non-profit department will hire a leadership team and employees to develop charitable projects in areas such as healthcare, education, and science.

Source:[std.stheadline.com](https://std.stheadline.com/realtime/article/2043965/%E5%8D%B3%E6%99%82-%E8%B2%A1%E7%B6%93-OpenAI%E8%A8%88%E5%8A%83%E9%87%8D%E7%B5%84%E5%85%AC%E5%8F%B8%E7%B5%90%E6%A7%8B-%E6%8E%A1%E5%85%AC%E7%9B%8A%E4%BC%81%E6%A5%AD%E6%A8%A1%E5%BC%8F-%E9%83%A8%E5%88%86%E8%AE%8A%E8%BA%AB%E7%87%9F%E5%88%A9%E6%A9%9F%E6%A7%8B)

**Why OpenAI plans transition to public benefit corporation**
OpenAI plans to transition its for-profit arm into a Delaware public benefit corporation (PBC) to raise capital and stay ahead in the AI race. A PBC is a for-profit entity that is legally required to pursue one or more public benefits, including social and environmental goals. OpenAI's new structure aims to make a more investor-friendly corporation while maintaining a mission of funding a related charity. Rivals such as Anthropic and xAI have also adopted the PBC structure. According to Ann Lipton, a corporate law professor at Tulane Law School, becoming a benefit corporation does not guarantee a company will put its stated mission above profit, as the law only requires the board to 'balance' its mission and profit-making interests. 'The only reason to choose benefit form over any other corporate form is the declaration to the public. It doesn't actually have any real enforcement power behind it,' Lipton said. 
Original language: en
Publish date: December 28, 2024 05:57 AM
Source:[The Indian Express](https://indianexpress.com/article/technology/tech-news-technology/openai-transition-public-benefit-corporation-9748474/)

**OpenAI Reorganizes into Non-Profit and For-Profit Entities**
OpenAI has announced a reorganization of the company, separating into two entities: a non-profit and a for-profit organization. The non-profit organization will focus on the company's mission to ensure that general-purpose artificial intelligence (AGI) benefits humanity, while the for-profit organization will generate revenue to support the non-profit's efforts. The company's board of directors has evaluated the current structure and decided to create a Delaware Public Benefit Corporation (PBC), which will allow OpenAI to balance shareholder interests with the interests of stakeholders, including employees, customers, suppliers, and the environment. The PBC will issue common stock and will have a public benefit that aligns with OpenAI's mission. The non-profit organization will be sustainable and will have a significant amount of resources, with the existing for-profit company's important equity appearing as PBC shares. The PBC will operate and control OpenAI's business, while the non-profit organization will hire a leadership team and employees to focus on charitable activities in areas such as healthcare, education, and science. OpenAI's mission is to ensure that AGI benefits humanity, and the company is seeking to develop a sustainable model to achieve this goal.
Original language: zh
Publish date: December 28, 2024 12:25 AM
Source:[凤凰网（凤凰新媒体）](https://tech.ifeng.com/c/8ffQQjnmw6j)

**OpenAI to Become a Public Benefit Corporation**
OpenAI plans to transform its for-profit branch into a Delaware Public Benefit Corporation (PBC) to raise capital and stay competitive in the costly AI race against companies like Google. The new structure aims to make OpenAI a more attractive investment opportunity while maintaining its mission to fund a connected charity. Similar to competitors like Anthropic, OpenAI will balance social and environmental goals with shareholder value. A PBC is a type of corporation that is legally required to pursue one or more public benefit goals, including social and environmental objectives. OpenAI's current structure is described as 'a for-profit entity, controlled by a non-profit organization, with a profit cap for investors and employees.' In the new organization, the non-profit organization will hold shares in the for-profit entity, just like external investors, and the for-profit entity will fund the charity's mission. According to OpenAI, 'the PBC will direct and control the operations and activities of OpenAI, while the non-profit organization will hire a management team and staff to pursue charitable initiatives in areas such as healthcare, education, and science.' Unlike PBCs, non-profit organizations do not have shareholders and reinvest profits into their mission rather than distributing them to individuals. PBCs do not have special tax exemptions or incentives, whereas non-profit organizations are generally exempt from federal income tax if they meet certain conditions. According to Ann Lipton, professor of corporate law at Tulane Law School, becoming a PBC does not guarantee that the company will prioritize its declared mission over profit, as the law only requires the board to 'balance' its mission and financial interests. The Delaware law requires the company to report to shareholders on the progress made in achieving its objectives, which, in practice, determines to what extent a PBC adheres to its mission, explains Lipton. 'The only reason to choose this form of corporation over another is the public declaration. There is no real enforcement power behind it,' added Lipton. Some legal experts also argue that listed PBCs are more likely to be acquired, as bidders can argue that the company does not maximize its profits or that its public benefit goals are in conflict with the bidder's objectives.
Original language: fr
Publish date: December 27, 2024 10:43 PM
Source:[zonebourse.com](https://www.zonebourse.com/cours/action/MICROSOFT-CORPORATION-4835/actualite/Pourquoi-OpenAI-prevoit-elle-de-devenir-une-societe-d-utilite-publique--48660500/)

**OpenAI mulls plan for more conventional for-profit business**
OpenAI, a decade-old research organization, is considering a change to its structure to create a more conventional for-profit business alongside a nonprofit arm. According to a blog post, the board is evaluating a plan to turn OpenAI's business into a public benefit corporation, which would allow it to pursue income while still aiming to better society. The nonprofit arm would hold shares in the for-profit entity, and the business would become a Delaware Public Benefit Corp. OpenAI's existing for-profit arm is currently controlled by its nonprofit organization, but under the proposal, the nonprofit entity would continue to exist and hold a 'significant interest' in the for-profit arm. As OpenAI's board said, 'The nonprofit entity would be one of the best-resourced nonprofits in history, and would hold a significant interest in the for-profit arm, in the form of shares determined by independent financial advisers at a fair valuation.' 
Original language: en
Publish date: December 27, 2024 10:03 PM
Source:[Azeri - Press Informasiya Agentliyi](https://en.apa.az/america/openai-mulls-plan-for-more-conventional-for-profit-business-456825)

**OpenAI Considers New Structure: A Revolution in Corporate Governance for Profit and Non-Profit Arms**
OpenAI is considering a significant restructuring of its corporate structure to address growing criticism and ensure a balance between commercial interests and social benefit. The company is evaluating the possibility of transforming its for-profit division into a Delaware Public Benefit Corporation (PBC), which would require the company to balance the interests of shareholders with those of the company and stakeholders. According to OpenAI, this conversion would allow the company to raise capital with more favorable terms, in line with the practices adopted by other innovative companies. The new structure could also strengthen the non-profit component of the organization, enabling the hiring of specialized personnel for charitable projects in the fields of health, education, and science. As stated in the company's post, 'The PBC will allow us to pursue our mission of generating value for society while maintaining a balance between economic and public interest objectives.' The current structure of OpenAI has been criticized since 2019, when the company decided to establish a for-profit division alongside the original non-profit foundation. This decision was motivated by the need to raise significant capital to support the development of complex artificial intelligence models. However, many observers have accused OpenAI of betraying its original mission. Criticisms have intensified in 2024, when Elon Musk, co-founder of OpenAI, filed a lawsuit against the company and its CEO Sam Altman, alleging that the leadership of OpenAI had manipulated his involvement, exploiting his ethical concerns about the risks of artificial intelligence to transform the organization into a purely commercial entity. According to the lawsuit, OpenAI had 'abandoned philanthropic principles' to focus on high profits, attracting the ire not only of Musk but also of other critics in the sector, such as David Sacks, a prominent consultant to the Trump administration. The proposal for restructuring comes at a time when artificial intelligence is becoming increasingly central in multiple sectors, from blockchain to healthcare. According to VanEck, a wealth manager, by 2025, agents of artificial intelligence created with models like ChatGPT will have a more significant role in decentralized communities, with an estimated population of one million active agents.
Original language: it
Publish date: December 27, 2024 08:38 PM
Source:[cryptonomist.ch](https://cryptonomist.ch/2024/12/27/openai-rivoluzione-governance-rami-profit-e-non/)

**OpenAI Abandons Non-Profit Model, Becomes For-Profit Company**
OpenAI, the company behind ChatGPT, has announced that it will abandon its non-profit model and become a for-profit company starting in 2025. The company, founded in 2015 as a research laboratory, has received $10 billion in investment from Microsoft in 2023. CEO Sam Altman stated, 'We need to become more than a laboratory and a startup: we need to transform into a durable company.' The company will become a Delaware Public Benefit Corporation (PBC), which requires balancing the interests of shareholders, stakeholders, and the public interest in business decisions. This move has been criticized by Elon Musk, who co-founded OpenAI in 2015 and has expressed concerns about the company's shift towards a profit-driven model, which he believes may compromise the development of ethical and secure AI technologies. Musk has also launched a lawsuit to block the conversion of OpenAI into a for-profit entity, arguing that it violates the company's founding principles and poses a risk to humanity.

**OpenAI Considers New Corporate Structure with Focus on Profitability**
OpenAI plans to implement a new corporate structure in 2025, aiming to become a 'public benefit corporation' (PBC). This new model would allow the company to manage its commercial operations while maintaining a non-profit division focused on social impact areas such as health, education, and science. According to the OpenAI board, 'hundreds of billions of dollars that large companies are investing in AI development show what is really needed for OpenAI to continue pursuing its mission.' The company is in discussions with regulators in California and Delaware to adopt the Delaware PBC model. The non-profit division would have a 'significant participation' in the PBC, determined by independent financial consultants. OpenAI's current structure is complex, having started as a non-profit in 2015 and later adopting a 'profit limited' model in 2019. However, this structure does not allow the board to consider the interests of those who finance the company directly.

**OpenAI Considers Structural Changes to Become Public Benefit Corporation**
OpenAI is considering a structural change to become a public benefit corporation (PBC) while maintaining a non-profit division. The board of directors is reviewing a plan to transform the business into a PBC, which can generate revenue while improving society, while keeping a non-profit division. According to the proposed plan, the non-profit division would hold shares in the for-profit entity. The company has been in talks with regulators in California and Delaware about the possible change. Elon Musk, co-founder and initial investor of OpenAI, has filed a lawsuit against the company in August, alleging that it violated an agreement to operate as a non-profit organization. The OpenAI board stated that the proposed plan would ensure the long-term success of the for-profit arm of the company, help the non-profit organization to raise funds and execute its mission more effectively, and allow the non-profit division to pursue beneficial initiatives in areas such as healthcare, education, and science more efficiently. 'This plan would allow us to pursue our mission more effectively while also generating revenue to support our work,' said the OpenAI board. 'We believe this structure will enable us to make a greater impact and create a more sustainable future for our organization.'
